standard_metadata.standard_description: Convert among different-sized standard measurement units within a given measurement system (e.g., convert 5 cm to 0.05 m), and use these conversions in solving multi-step, real world problems.

question.content: Louis made $24 \text{ quarts}$ of lemonade. He divided the lemonade equally between $6$ pitchers.    **How  many *quarts* of  lemonade did Louis put in each pitcher?**     quarts  Convert the number of quarts to pints.  **How  many *pints* of  lemonade did Louis put in each pitcher?**     pints

hints.content: Louis divided $24\text{ quarts}$ into $6$ pitchers.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{24}\text{ quarts } \div \goldE6 ={} \maroonD{?}\text{ quarts}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 24. The bottom rectangle is divided into 6 equal parts, each labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 6 equal groups.

hints.content: Each pitcher contained $\maroonD4 \text{ quarts}$ of lemonade.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{24}\text{ quarts } \div \goldE6 = \maroonD{4}\text{ quarts}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 24. The bottom rectangle is divided into 6 equal parts, each labeled 4. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 6 equal groups.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\maroonD4\text{ quarts}$ to pints.  $1 \text{ quart} = 2\text{ pints}$  So,  $\begin{align} \maroonD4\text{ quarts}&=\maroonD4\text{ quarts} \times {2\text{ pints per quart}} \\\\ &= \maroonD8 \text{ pints} \end{align}$
Louis put $\maroonD4$ quarts of lemonade in each pitcher.  Louis put $\maroonD8$ pints of lemonade in each pitcher.

question.content: Bob was throwing a party. He had $22$ pints of soda before the party started. At the end of the party, there were $8$ pints of soda left.   **How  many *pints* of  soda were drank during the party?**     pints  Convert the number of pints to cups.  **How  many *cups* of  soda were drank during the party?**     cups

hints.content: Bob started with $22$ pints of soda. At the end of the party, there were $8$ pints left.   [[☃ image 1]]    $\purpleD{?} + \blueE{8}\text{ pints} = \greenD{22}\text{ pints}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 22. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Pints of soda. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is shaded purple and is labeled question mark. The second part is shaded blue and is labeled 8. Across the purple part is a curved bracket labeled Soda drank. Across the blue part is a curved bracket labeled Soda left.

hints.content: $14$ pints of soda were drank during the party.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{14}\text{ pints} + \blueE{8}\text{ pints} = \maroonD{22}\text{ pints}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 22. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Pints of soda. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is shaded purple and is labeled 14. The second part is shaded blue and is labeled 8. Across the purple part is a curved bracket labeled Soda drank. Across the blue part is a curved bracket labeled Soda left.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\purpleD{14}\text{ pints}$ to cups.  $1 \text{ pint} = 2\text{ cups}$  So,  $\begin{align} \purpleD{14}\text{ pints}&=\purpleD{14}\text{ pints} \times {2\text{ cups per pint}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{28} \text{ cups} \end{align}$
They drank $\purpleD{14}$ pints of soda during the party.  They drank $\purpleD{28}$ cups of soda during the party.

question.content: A fish tank has $240$ quarts of water. Levi adds another $120$ quarts to the tank.  **How  many *quarts* of  water are in the fish tank?**     quarts  Convert the number of quarts to gallons.  **How  many *gallons* of  water are in the fish tank?**     gallons

hints.content: The fish tank has $240$ quarts of water. Levi adds $120$ quarts.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{240}\text{ quarts}  + \blueE{120}\text{ quarts} = \maroonD{?}\text{ quarts}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Fish tank capacity. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is shaded purple and is labeled 240. The second part is shaded blue and is labeled 120. Across the purple part is a curved bracket labeled Capacity before added water. Across the blue part is a curved bracket labeled water added.

hints.content: There is a total capacity of $360$ quarts.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{240}\text{ quarts}  + \blueE{120}\text{ quarts}= \maroonD{360}\text{ quarts}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 360. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Fish tank capacity. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is shaded purple and is labeled 240. The second part is shaded blue and is labeled 120. Across the purple part is a curved bracket labeled Capacity before added water. Across the blue part is a curved bracket labeled water added.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\maroonD{360}\text{ quarts}$ to gallons.  $1 \text{ quart} =\dfrac{1}{4}\text{ gallon}$  So,  $\begin{align} \maroonD{360}\text{ quarts}&=\maroonD{360}\text{ quarts} \times \dfrac{1\text{ gallon}}{4\text{ quarts}} \\\\ &=\dfrac{\maroonD{360}\cancel{\text{ quarts}}}{1} \times \dfrac{1\text{ gallon}}{4\cancel{\text{ quarts}}} \\\\ &=\dfrac{\maroonD{360}\text{ gallons}}{4}\\\\ &={\maroonD{360}\text{ gallons}}\div{4}\\\\ &= \maroonD{90} \text{ gallons} \end{align}$
There are $\maroonD{360}$ quarts of water in the fish tank.  There are $\maroonD{90}$ gallons of water in the fish tank.

question.content: Kami's fitness trainer recommends that she drinks $12$ fluid ounces of water $8$ times a day.   **How many *fluid ounces* does Kami drink in one day?**   oz  Convert number of fluid ounces to cups.  **How many *cups* does Kami drink in one day?**   cups

hints.content: Kami has to drink $12$ fluid ounces $8$ times a day.  [[☃ image 1]]   $\maroonD{12}\text{ oz} \times \blueE{8} = ~\purpleD{?}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. The bottom rectangle is divided into 8 equal parts, each labeled 12. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 8 equal groups.

hints.content: She drinks $96$ fluid ounces a day.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonD{12}\text{ oz} \times \blueE{8} = ~\purpleD{96}\text{ oz}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 96. The bottom rectangle is divided into 8 equal parts, each labeled 12. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 8 equal groups.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\purpleD{96}\text{ ounces}$ to cups.  $1 \text{ ounce} =\dfrac{1}{8}\text{ cup}$  So,  $\begin{align} \purpleD{96}\text{ ounces}&=\purpleD{96}\text{ ounces} \times \dfrac{1\text{ cups}}{8\text{ ounces}} \\\\ &=\dfrac{\purpleD{96}\cancel{\text{ ounces}}}{1} \times \dfrac{1\text{ cups}}{8\cancel{\text{ ounces}}} \\\\ &=\dfrac{\purpleD{96}\text{ cups}}{8}\\\\ &={\purpleD{96}\text{ cups}}\div{8}\\\\ &= \purpleD{12} \text{ cups} \end{align}$
Kami drinks $\purpleE{96}$ fluid ounces of water a day.  Kami drinks $\purpleE{12}$ cups of water a day.

question.content: Jess picked $40$ pounds of peaches in her orchard. She divided the peaches evenly between $4$ large baskets.   **How  many *pounds* of  peaches did Jess put in each basket?**     pounds  Convert the number of pounds to ounces.  **How  many *ounces* of  peaches did Jess put in each basket?**     ounces

hints.content: Jess divided $40$ pounds of peaches into $4$ large baskets.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleE{40}\text{ pounds} \div \tealE4 ={} \maroonE{?}\text{ pounds}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 40. The bottom rectangle is divided into 4 equal parts, each labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 4 equal groups.

hints.content: Each basket contained $\maroonD{10} \text{ pounds}$ of peaches.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleE{40}\text{ pounds} \div \tealE4 = \maroonE{10}\text{ pounds}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 40. The bottom rectangle is divided into 4 equal parts, each labeled 10. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 4 equal groups.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\maroonE{10}\text{ pounds}$ to ounces.  $1 \text{ pound} = 16\text{ ounces}$  So,   $\begin{align} \maroonE{10}\text{ pounds}&=\maroonE{10}\text{ pounds} \times {16\text{ ounces per pound}} \\\\ &= \maroonE{160} \text{ ounces} \end{align}$
Jess put $\maroonE{10}$ pounds of peaches in each basket.  Jess put $\maroonE{160}$ ounces of peaches in each basket.

question.content: Oswaldo is cooking a big dinner. He buys $30\dfrac{1}{2}$ ounces of sweet potatoes, $13\dfrac{1}{4}$ ounces of asparagus and $20\dfrac{1}{4}$ ounces of squash.  **How  many *ounces* of  vegetables did Oswaldo buy altogether?**     ounces  Convert the number of ounces to pounds.  **How  many *pounds* of  vegetables did Oswaldo buy altogether?**     pounds

hints.content: Oswaldo bought $30\dfrac{1}{2}$ ounces of sweet potatoes, $13\dfrac{1}{4}$ ounces of asparagus and $20\dfrac{1}{4}$ ounces of squash.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{30\dfrac{1}{2}}\text{ oz} + \blueE{13\dfrac{1}{4}}\text{ oz} + \maroonD{20\dfrac{1}{4}}\text{ oz} = ~\goldE{?}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total ounces bought. The bottom rectangle is divided into 3 unequal parts. The first part is shaded purple and is labeled 30 and one-half. The second part is shaded blue and is labeled 13 and one-fourth. The third part is shaded pink and is labeled 20 and one-fourth. Across the purple part is a curved bracket labeled sweet potato. Across the blue part is a curved bracket labeled asparagus. Across the pink part is a curved bracket labeled squash.

hints.content: Oswaldo bought $\goldE{64}$ ounces of vegetables.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{30\dfrac{1}{2}}\text{ oz} + \blueE{13\dfrac{1}{4}}\text{ oz} + \maroonD{20\dfrac{1}{4}}\text{ oz} = ~\goldE{64}\text{ oz}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 64. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total ounces bought. The bottom rectangle is divided into 3 unequal parts. The first part is shaded purple and is labeled 30 and one-half. The second part is shaded blue and is labeled 13 and one-fourth. The third part is shaded pink and is labeled 20 and one-fourth. Across the purple part is a curved bracket labeled sweet potato. Across the blue part is a curved bracket labeled asparagus. Across the pink part is a curved bracket labeled squash.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\goldE{64}\text{ ounces}$ to pounds.  $1 \text{ ounce} = \dfrac{1}{16}\text{ pound}$  So,   $\begin{align} \goldE{64}\text{ ounces}&=\goldE{64}\text{ ounces} \times \dfrac{1\text{ pound}}{16\text{ ounces}} \\\\ &=\dfrac{\goldE{64}\cancel{\text{ ounces}}}{1} \times \dfrac{1\text{ pound}}{16\cancel{\text{ ounces}}} \\\\ &=\dfrac{\goldE{64}\text{ pounds}}{16}\\\\ &=\goldE{64}\text{ pounds}\div{16}\\\\ &= \goldE{4} \text{ pounds} \end{align}$
Oswaldo bought $ \goldE{64} \text{ ounces}$ of vegetables.  Oswaldo bought $ \goldE{4} \text{ pounds}$ of vegetables.

question.content: Luke bought $256$ ounces of strawberries. He divided them evenly between $8$ different pies.  **How  many *ounces* of  strawberries did Luke put into each pie?**   ounces  Convert the number of ounces to pounds.  **How  many *pounds* of  strawberries did Luke put into each pie?**   pounds

hints.content: Luke divided $256$ ounces of strawberries into $8$ pies.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{256}\text{ ounces} \div \blueE8 = {}\maroonD{?}\text{ ounces}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 256. The bottom rectangle is divided into 8 equal parts, each labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 8 equal groups.

hints.content: Luke places $\maroonD{32}$ ounces into each pie.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{256}\text{ ounces} \div \blueE8 = \maroonD{32}\text{ ounces}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 256. The bottom rectangle is divided into 8 equal parts, each labeled 32. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 8 equal groups.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\maroonD{32}\text{ ounces}$ to pounds.  $1 \text{ ounce} = \dfrac{1}{16}\text{ pound}$  So,   $\begin{align} \maroonD{32}\text{ ounces}&=\maroonD{32}\text{ ounces} \times \dfrac{1\text{ pound}}{16\text{ ounces}} \\\\ &=\dfrac{\maroonD{32}\cancel{\text{ ounces}}}{1} \times \dfrac{1\text{ pound}}{16\cancel{\text{ ounces}}} \\\\ &=\dfrac{\maroonD{32}\text{ pounds}}{16}\\\\ &=\maroonD{32}\text{ pounds}\div{16}\\\\ &= \maroonD{2} \text{ pounds} \end{align}$
Luke put $\maroonD{32}$ ounces of strawberries in each pie.  Luke put $\maroonD{2}$ pounds of strawberries in each pie.

question.content: Xan and Katie are twins.  Xan weighs $6$ pounds $9$ ounces, and Katie weighs $8$ pounds $1$ ounce.    **What is each twin's weight in *ounces*?**  Xan's weight:  ounces  Katie's weight:   ounces  **What is the difference, in *ounces*, between Xan and Katie's weight?**     ounces

hints.content: First, let's convert Xan's weight to ounces only. He weighed $6$ pounds $9$ ounces.  $1 \text{ pound} = 16\text{ ounces}$  So,  $\begin{align}\purpleD{6}\text{ pounds}&=\purpleD{6}\text{ pounds} \times {16\text{ ounces per pound}} \\\\ &= \purpleD{96} \text{ ounces} \end{align}$  Now, we can add the $9$ ounces.  $\purpleD{96}\text{ ounces} + 9\text{ ounces} = \purpleD{105}\text{ ounces}$

Next, let's convert Katie's weight to ounces only. She weighed $8$ pounds $1$ ounce.   $\begin{align}\goldE{8}\text{ pounds}&=\goldE{8}\text{ pounds} \times {16\text{ ounces per pound}} \\\\ &= \goldE{128} \text{ ounces} \end{align}$  Now, we can add the $1$ ounce.  $\goldE{128}\text{ ounces} + 1\text{ ounce} = \goldE{129}\text{ ounces}$
Now, we can find the difference between Katie and Xan's weight.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\goldE{129}\text{ oz} - \purpleD{105}\text{ oz} = ~\blueE{?}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 129. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Katie’s weight. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is shaded purple and is labeled 105. The second part is shaded blue and is labeled question mark. Across the purple part is a curved bracket labeled Xan’s weight. Across the blue part is a curved bracket labeled difference.

hints.content: The difference is $\blueE{24}\text{ ounces}$.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\goldE{129}\text{ oz} - \purpleD{105}\text{ oz} = ~\blueE{24}\text{ oz}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 129. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Katie’s weight. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is shaded purple and is labeled 105. The second part is shaded blue and is labeled 24. Across the purple part is a curved bracket labeled Xan’s weight. Across the blue part is a curved bracket labeled difference.

hints.content: Xan's weight is $\purpleD{105}\text{ ounces}$.  Katie's weight is $\goldE{129}\text{ ounces}$.  The difference between Katie and Xan's weight is $\blueE{24}\text{ ounces}$.

question.content: Sam built the same length of fence each day. At the end of $6$ days, the fence was $54$ feet long.  **How  many *feet* of fence did Sam build each day?**     feet  Convert the number of feet to inches.  **How  many *inches* of fence did Sam build each day?**     inches

hints.content: Sam built $54$ feet of fence over $6$ days.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleE{54}\text{ feet} \div \tealE6 = \maroonE{?}\text{ feet}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 54. The bottom rectangle is divided into 6 equal parts, each labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 6 equal groups.

hints.content: Each day she built $\maroonE{9} \text{ feet}$ of fence.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleE{54}\text{ feet} \div \tealE6 = \maroonE{9}\text{ feet}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 54. The bottom rectangle is divided into 6 equal parts, each labeled 9. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 6 equal groups.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\maroonE9\text{ feet}$ to inches.  $1 \text{ foot} = 12\text{ inches}$  So,   $\begin{align} \maroonE9\text{ feet}&=\maroonE9\text{ feet} \times {12\text{ inches per foot}} \\\\ &= \maroonE{108} \text{ inches} \end{align}$
Sam built $\maroonE{9}$ feet of fence each day.  Sam built $\maroonE{108}$ inches of fence each day.

question.content: A kangaroo hopped first $3{,}520$ yards to the lake with her baby in her pouch.  She hopped the remaining $5{,}280$ yards without her baby in her pouch.   **How many *yards* did the kangaroo hop to the lake?**     yards  Convert the number of yards to miles.  **How many *miles* did the kangaroo hop to the lake?**     miles

hints.content: The kangaroo hopped $3{,}520$ yards with her baby in her pouch. She hopped $5{,}280$ yards without her baby in her pouch.    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{3{,}520}\text{ yds} + \maroonD{5{,}280}\text{ yds} = ~\purpleD{?}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total yards hopped. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is shaded blue and is labeled 3,520. The second part is shaded pink and is labeled 5,280. Across the blue part is a curved bracket labeled with baby. Across the pink part is a curved bracket labeled without baby.

hints.content: The kangaroo hopped $8{,}800$ yards to the lake.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueE{3{,}520}\text{ yds} + \maroonD{5{,}280}\text{ yds} = ~\purpleD{8{,}800}\text{ yds}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 8,800. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled Total yards hopped. The bottom rectangle is divided into 2 unequal parts. The first part is shaded blue and is labeled 3,520. The second part is shaded pink and is labeled 5,280. Across the blue part is a curved bracket labeled with baby. Across the pink part is a curved bracket labeled without baby.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\purpleD{8{,}800}\text{ yds}$ to miles.  $1 \text { yard} = \dfrac{1}{1{,}760}\text{ mile}$  So,   $\begin{align} \purpleD{8{,}800}\text{ yards}&=\purpleD{8{,}800}\text{ yards} \times \dfrac{1\text{ miles}}{{1{,}760}\text{ yards}}\\\\ &=\purpleD{8{,}800}\cancel{\text{ yards}} \times \dfrac{1\text{ miles}}{{1{,}760}\cancel{\text{ yards}}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\purpleD{8{,}800}\text{ miles}}{1{,}760}\\\\ &=\purpleD{8{,}800}\text{ miles}\div{1{,}760}\\\\ &=\purpleD5\text{ miles} \end{align}$
The kangaroo hopped $\purpleD{8{,}800}$ yards.  The kangaroo hopped $\purpleD{5}$ miles.

question.content: Shawntell is training for a relay race. She ran $2{,}000$ feet every day for $6$ days.  **In total, how  many *feet* did Shawntell run?**   feet  Convert the number of feet to yards.  **In total, how  many *yards* did Shawntell run?**     yards

hints.content: Shawntell ran $2{,}000$ feet for $6$ days.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonD{2{,}000}\text{ feet}\times\blueE6 = \purpleD{?}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled question mark. The bottom rectangle is divided into 6 equal parts, each labeled 2000. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 6 equal groups.

hints.content: Shawntell ran $12{,}000$ feet altogether.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\maroonD{2{,}000}\text{ feet}\times\blueE6 = \purpleD{12{,}000}\text{ feet}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 12000. The bottom rectangle is divided into 6 equal parts, each labeled 2000. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 6 equal groups.

hints.content: Now, we need to convert $\purpleD{12{,}000}\text{ feet}$ to yards.  $1 \text { foot} = \dfrac{1}{3}\text{ yard}$  So,   $\begin{align} \purpleD{12{,}000}\text{ feet}&=\purpleD{12{,}000}\text{ feet}\times \dfrac{1\text{ yard}}{{3}\text{ feet}}\\\\ &=\purpleD{12{,}000}\cancel{\text{ feet}} \times \dfrac{1\text{ yard}}{{3}\cancel{\text{ feet}}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\purpleD{12{,}000}\text{ yards}}{3}\\\\ &=\purpleD{12{,}000}\text{ yards}\div{3}\\\\ &=\purpleD{4{,}000}\text{ yards} \end{align}$
Shawntell ran $\purpleD{12{,}000}$ feet.  Shawntell ran $\purpleD{4{,}000}$ yards.

question.content: Marlo buys $6$ feet of ribbon to make bracelets. She needs $18$ inches of ribbon to make one bracelet.   **How many *inches* of ribbon does Marlo buy?**   inches  **How many bracelets can Marlo make if she uses all the ribbon she buys?**   bracelets

hints.content: Marlo has $6$ feet of ribbon. Let's turn the $6$ feet of ribbon into inches.  $1 \text { foot} =12\text{ inches}$  So,   $\begin{align} \purpleD{6}\text{ feet}&=\purpleD{6}\text{ feet}\times 12 \text{ inches per ft}\\\\ &=\purpleD{72}\text{ inches} \end{align}$
Marlo has $\purpleD{72}$ inches of ribbon. Each bracelet uses $18$ inches of ribbon.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{72}\text{ inches} \div \maroonD{18}\text{ inches} = ~ \blueE{?}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of unequal length. The top rectangle is labeled 72. The bottom rectangle is shorter and labeled 18. A curved bracket across the bottom and the width of the top rectangle is labeled with a question mark and the words equal groups.

hints.content: Marlo can make $\blueE{4}$ bracelets.   [[☃ image 1]]  $\purpleD{72}\text{ inches} \div \maroonD{18}\text{ inches} = ~ \blueE{4}$

images.alt: Two rectangles of equal length. The top rectangle is labeled 72. The bottom rectangle is divided into 4 equal parts, each labeled 18. Across the rectangle is a curved bracket labeled 4 equal groups.

hints.content: Marlo buys $\purpleD{72}$ inches of ribbon.  Marlo can make $\blueE{4}$ bracelets.
